entry.title: Derivation of Euler's number
entry.content:
e = 2.71828â€¦

This is what defines the magical Eulerâ€™s number:

ddx2x=2x+â–³xâˆ’2xâ–³x=2x(2â–³xâˆ’1â–³x)2â–³xâˆ’1â–³xâ‰Š0.6931...ddx3x=3x+â–³xâˆ’3xâ–³x=3x(3â–³xâˆ’1â–³x)3â–³xâˆ’1â–³xâ‰Š1.0986...::ddx8x=8x+â–³xâˆ’8xâ–³x=8x(8â–³xâˆ’1â–³x)8â–³xâˆ’1â–³xâ‰Š2.0794...\begin{aligned} &\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}2^x\\ &=\frac{2^{x+ \triangle x}-2^x}{\triangle x}\\ &=2^x(\frac{2^{\triangle x}-1}{\triangle x})\\ &\frac{2^{\triangle x}-1}{\triangle x}\approxeq 0.6931...\\ &\\ &\\ &\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}3^x\\ &=\frac{3^{x+ \triangle x}-3^x}{\triangle x}\\ &=3^x(\frac{3^{\triangle x}-1}{\triangle x})\\ &\frac{3^{\triangle x}-1}{\triangle x}\approxeq 1.0986...\\ &:\\ &:\\ &\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}8^x\\ &=\frac{8^{x+ \triangle x}-8^x}{\triangle x}\\ &=8^x(\frac{8^{\triangle x}-1}{\triangle x})\\ &\frac{8^{\triangle x}-1}{\triangle x}\approxeq 2.0794...\\ \end{aligned} â€‹dxdâ€‹2x=â–³x2x+â–³xâˆ’2xâ€‹=2x(â–³x2â–³xâˆ’1â€‹)â–³x2â–³xâˆ’1â€‹â‰Š0.6931...dxdâ€‹3x=â–³x3x+â–³xâˆ’3xâ€‹=3x(â–³x3â–³xâˆ’1â€‹)â–³x3â–³xâˆ’1â€‹â‰Š1.0986...::dxdâ€‹8x=â–³x8x+â–³xâˆ’8xâ€‹=8x(â–³x8â–³xâˆ’1â€‹)â–³x8â–³xâˆ’1â€‹â‰Š2.0794...â€‹

In the sequence above,it is found out that the derivative of a base to the power of a variable is: $$base^{variable} \times constant$$

When the base is e, the constant = 1

ddxex=ex+â–³xâˆ’exâ–³x=ex(eâ–³xâˆ’1â–³x)eâ–³xâˆ’1â–³xâ‰Š1.000...\begin{aligned} &\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}e^x\\ &=\frac{e^{x+ \triangle x}-e^x}{\triangle x}\\ &=e^x(\frac{e^{\triangle x}-1}{\triangle x})\\ &\frac{e^{\triangle x}-1}{\triangle x}\approxeq 1.000...\\ \end{aligned} â€‹dxdâ€‹ex=â–³xex+â–³xâˆ’exâ€‹=ex(â–³xeâ–³xâˆ’1â€‹)â–³xeâ–³xâˆ’1â€‹â‰Š1.000...â€‹

entry.title: Derivative principle and rules
entry.content:
Made this during the anticipatory period during June 2023 till before I enter university. It gavve me deeper understanding of calculus and made foundation calculus course a lot easier ğŸ˜

$$\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}=fâ€™(x)$$

Measures best constant approximation for rate of change (at one point)

dy : change in y
dx : change in x

Derivative rules

Accuracy increases as the small change in x approaches zero.

First principle

fâ€²(x)=limâ¡hâ†’0f(x+h)âˆ’f(x)hf'(x)=\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\frac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{h} fâ€²(x)=hâ†’0limâ€‹hf(x+h)âˆ’f(x)â€‹

limit of h to 0 : h infinitely approaches 0
f(x+h) : function value after the change in x
f(x) : initial value of function
h : change in x

setting h -> 0 simplify problem
knowing first principle is useful in proving formulas

Lâ€™HÃ´pitalâ€™s rule (actually Bernoulli)

limâ¡hâ†’0f(x)g(x)=limâ¡hâ†’0fâ€²(x)gâ€²(x)\lim_{h\rightarrow0}\frac{f(x)}{g(x)}=\lim_{h\rightarrow0}\frac{f'(x)}{g'(x)} hâ†’0limâ€‹g(x)f(x)â€‹=hâ†’0limâ€‹gâ€²(x)fâ€²(x)â€‹

Power rule

d(xn)dx=nxnâˆ’1\frac{\mathrm{d}(x^n) }{\mathrm{d} x}=nx^{n-1} dxd(xn)â€‹=nxnâˆ’1

Reciprocal rule

fâˆ’1(x)=âˆ’fâ€²(x)f(x)2f^{-1}(x)=-\frac{f'(x)}{f(x)^2} fâˆ’1(x)=âˆ’f(x)2fâ€²(x)â€‹

Sum rule

ddx(g(x)+h(x))=gâ€²(x)+hâ€²(x)\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x}(g(x)+h(x))=g'(x) + h'(x) dxdâ€‹(g(x)+h(x))=gâ€²(x)+hâ€²(x)

One by one, straightforward

Chain rule

ddxg(h(x))=dgdh(h(x))dhdx(x)\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x}g(h(x))=\frac{\mathrm{d}g }{\mathrm{d}h}(h(x))\frac{\mathrm{d} h}{\mathrm{d} x}(x) dxdâ€‹g(h(x))=dhdgâ€‹(h(x))dxdhâ€‹(x)

Product rule

ddx[g(x)h(x)]=gâ€²(x)h(x)+g(x)hâ€²(x)\frac{\mathrm {d} }{\mathrm {d}x}[g(x)h(x)]=g'(x)h(x)+g(x)h'(x) dxdâ€‹[g(x)h(x)]=gâ€²(x)h(x)+g(x)hâ€²(x)

Quotient rule

ddx[g(x)h(x)]=h(x)gâ€²(x)âˆ’g(x)hâ€²(x)[h(x)]2\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}[\frac{g(x)}{h(x)}]=\frac{h(x)g'(x)-g(x)h'(x)}{[h(x)]^2} dxdâ€‹[h(x)g(x)â€‹]=[h(x)]2h(x)gâ€²(x)âˆ’g(x)hâ€²(x)â€‹

Common derivatives

Derivatives Derivation
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(x)=1$$ $$nx^{n-1}$$ and [[Derivation of power rule]]
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\sin x)=\cos x$$ [[Derivation of trig derivatives]]
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\cos x)=-\sin x$$ Same as above
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\tan x)=\sec^2 x$$ ~
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\sec x)=\sec x \tan x$$ ~
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\csc x)=-\csc x \cot x$$ ~
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\cot x)=-\csc^2 x$$ ~
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\sin^{-1}x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}$$
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\cos^{-1}x)=-\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}$$
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\tan^{-1}x)=\frac{1}{1+x^2}$$
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(a^x)=a^x\ln a$$ [[Derivation of Eulerâ€™s number differentiation rule]]
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(e^x)=e^x$$ [[Eulerâ€™s number]],[[Derivation of Eulerâ€™s number differentiation rule]]
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\ln x)=\frac{1}{x}, x>0$$ Refer [Implicit differentiation]
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\ln \mid x\mid)=\frac{1}{x}, x \neq 0$$
$$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\log_ax)=\frac{1}{x\ln a},x>0$$

Implicit differentiation

Differentiation of implicit equations, where:

  • two or more variables are interdependent on each other

  • example:

x^2+y^2=5$$$$\sin(x)y^2=x$$$$y=\ln(x)

Approach: basically differentiate then arrange

x2+y2=5d(x2+y2=5)2xdx+2ydy=02x2y=dydx\begin{aligned} &x^2+y^2=5\\ &\mathrm{d}(x^2+y^2=5)\\ &2x\mathrm{d}x + 2y\mathrm{d}y = 0\\ &\frac{2x}{2y}=\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} \end{aligned} â€‹x2+y2=5d(x2+y2=5)2xdx+2ydy=02y2xâ€‹=dxdyâ€‹â€‹

sinâ¡(x)y2=xd(sinâ¡(x)y2)=dxcosâ¡(x)dxâˆ—y2+2ydyâˆ—sinâ¡(x)=dxdydx=1âˆ’cosâ¡(x)y22ysinâ¡(x)\begin{aligned} &\sin(x)y^2=x\\ &\mathrm{d}(\sin(x)y^2)=\mathrm{d}x\\ &\cos(x)\mathrm{d}x*y^2+2y\mathrm{d}y*\sin(x)=\mathrm{d}x\\ &\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}=\frac{1-\cos(x)y^2}{2y\sin(x)} \end{aligned} â€‹sin(x)y2=xd(sin(x)y2)=dxcos(x)dxâˆ—y2+2ydyâˆ—sin(x)=dxdxdyâ€‹=2ysin(x)1âˆ’cos(x)y2â€‹â€‹

y=lnâ¡(x)ey=xd(ey)=dxeydy=dxdydx=1ey=1x\begin{aligned} &y=\ln(x)\\ &e^y=x\\ &\mathrm{d}(e^y)=\mathrm{d}x\\ &e^y\mathrm{d}y=\mathrm{d}x\\ &\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}=\frac{1}{e^y}=\frac{1}{x}\\ \end{aligned} â€‹y=ln(x)ey=xd(ey)=dxeydy=dxdxdyâ€‹=ey1â€‹=x1â€‹â€‹

entry.title: Chemistry experiments
entry.content:
Noting down 2023 foundation chemistry experiments. (Excellent academic integrity)

Analysis of vinegar

Equations:

CH3COOH+NaOHâ†’CH3COONa+H2O\mathrm{CH_3COOH+NaOH}\rightarrow\mathrm{CH_3COONa+H_2O} CH3â€‹COOH+NaOHâ†’CH3â€‹COONa+H2â€‹O

Neutralisation reaction

Precautions
  • Titrate slowly
  • Use white paper as background
  • Eye maintain parallel with meniscus when taking reading to avoid parallax error
Formula

0.003Ã—A.Titre0.003\times\mathrm{A.Titre} 0.003Ã—A.Titre

Anyway this was our first failed experiment, the content of vingear was way too high, perhaps we did the titrations too fast.

Analysis of bleach

Equations:

OClâˆ’+2Iâˆ’+2H+â†’I2+Clâˆ’+H2O\mathrm{OCl^- + 2I^- + 2H^+}\rightarrow\mathrm{I_2 + Cl^- + H_2O} OClâˆ’+2Iâˆ’+2H+â†’I2â€‹+Clâˆ’+H2â€‹O

  • Oxidizing agent: hypochlorite ion
  • Reducing agent: iodide ion and hydrogen ion

I2+2S2O32âˆ’â†’S4O62âˆ’+2Iâˆ’\mathrm{I_2 + 2S_2O_3^{2-}} \rightarrow \mathrm{S_4O_6^{2-} + 2I^-} I2â€‹+2S2â€‹O32âˆ’â€‹â†’S4â€‹O62âˆ’â€‹+2Iâˆ’

  • Oxidizing agent: iodine
  • Reducing agent: thiosulphate ion
Precautions
  • Pls invert the volumetric flask to produce homogenous solution
  • With each addition of thiosulfate, the concentration of I2Â decreases, and the brown colour will fade to a pale yellow colour then to colourless, making detection of the end point difficult, thus, a small amount of starch is added near the endpoint, in order to form a deep blue complex with iodine that is easy to observe
  • Eyes must maintain parallel with meniscus when taking reading to avoid parallax error
  • Rinse the apparatus with correct solution
Formula

[(A.TitreÃ·1000Ã—0.12)Ã·0.02]Ã—250Ã—74.45200\frac{[(\frac{\mathrm{A.Titre}\div1000\times 0.1}{2})\div 0.02]\times 250\times74.45}{200} 200[(2A.TitreÃ·1000Ã—0.1â€‹)Ã·0.02]Ã—250Ã—74.45â€‹

Expected result: 5%
Expected average titre: around 21.5

Percentage of error

âˆ£theoryâˆ’resultâˆ£theory\frac{\mid \mathrm{theory-result}\mid}{\mathrm{theory}} theoryâˆ£theoryâˆ’resultâˆ£â€‹

Discussion
  • back titration is performed to reduce the volume of titrant needed to complete decolourise the titrate
  • Put potassium iodide and sulphuric acid in immediately without leaving them out in the open air

This time our titration skills improved, but the results were still unsatisfactory (I think it is because I didnâ€™t mix up the solution in volumetric flask properly). Iâ€™m starting to realize our report is too å•°å—¦, but we werenâ€™t making changes because we thought the more the better.

Chromatography of inks

Precautions
  • make sure inner wall of beaker is dry
  • be careful
  • watch glass placed concave å‡¹ outwards (prevent particles from entering)
  • stop when liquid is 1cm from top of paper (be consistent with this)
  • IMMEDIATELY record the level with pencil
  • IMMEDIATELY put to entrance of fume chamber to
  • IMMEDIATELY circle the spot when paper is dry
  • For food dye, let spot dry then dip again
Retention value formula:

Rf=traveldistance_componenttraveldistance_solventR_f = \frac{\mathrm{traveldistance\_component}}{\mathrm{traveldistance\_solvent}} Rfâ€‹=traveldistance_solventtraveldistance_componentâ€‹

For such simple experiments we were only marked 2.9/3.75 ğŸ¥², because we forgot to label the colour columns, and our report is too long. Now that teacher hass pointed this out and we realized, we shall improve it.

Spectroscopy analysis

Precautions
  • make sure volumetric flask is inverted properly to create homogenous solution
  • Make sure transparent side of cuvette is clean
Formula to calculate concentration of diluted sodium salicylate

C1V1=C2V2C_1V_1=C_2V_2 C1â€‹V1â€‹=C2â€‹V2â€‹

sodium salicylate [C6H4(OH)COONa]
ratio of reaction between sodium salicylate and iron (III)        chloride = 1:1

We are seeing improvements in our report marks.

Factors affecting rate of reaction

Reaction (HCl + Na2S2O3):

S2O3(aq)+2H+(aq)â†’S(s)+SO2(g)+H2O(l)\mathrm{S}_2\mathrm{O}_3(aq) + 2\mathrm{H}^+(aq) \rightarrow \mathrm{S}(s) + \mathrm{SO}_2(g) + \mathrm{H}_2O(l) S2â€‹O3â€‹(aq)+2H+(aq)â†’S(s)+SO2â€‹(g)+H2â€‹O(l)

  • Careful (sodium thiosulphate is hygroscopic btw)
  • remember to blink when observing

I was å§”ä»¥é‡ä»» to determine the disappearance of the X mark, yet I failed almost everytime because I didnâ€™t blink during the observation and somehow the mark faded away from my view faster than it actually was. Nevertheless, it was ok.

Chemical equilibrium

Precaution
  • be honest and trust the result
  • handle cuvette carefully donâ€™t stain the transparent side
Data analysis
  1. Find concentration of Fe3+ and SCN- in each of the solutions.
  2. Find the concentration of FeSCN2+ at equilibrium using ratio of its absorbance against the standard FeSCN2+ solution absorbance:

FeSCN2+(eq)=MstandardÃ—abssolutionabsstandard\mathrm{FeSCN^{2+}}_{(eq)} = \mathrm{M_{standard}} \times \frac{abs_{solution}}{abs_{standard}} FeSCN2+(eq)â€‹=Mstandardâ€‹Ã—absstandardâ€‹abssolutionâ€‹â€‹

  1. Calculate the concentration of Fe3+ and SCN- at equilibrium using ICE method:

Fe3+eq=FeSCN2+eqâˆ’Fe3+0SCNâˆ’eq=FeSCN2+eqâˆ’SCNâˆ’0\begin{aligned} \\&\mathrm{Fe^{3+}}_{eq}=\mathrm{FeSCN^{2+}}_{eq} - \mathrm{Fe^{3+}}_{0} \\&\mathrm{SCN^{-}}_{eq}=\mathrm{FeSCN^{2+}}_{eq} - \mathrm{SCN^{-}}_{0} \end{aligned}â€‹Fe3+eqâ€‹=FeSCN2+eqâ€‹âˆ’Fe3+0â€‹SCNâˆ’eqâ€‹=FeSCN2+eqâ€‹âˆ’SCNâˆ’0â€‹â€‹

  1. Calculate the equilibrium constant:

Kc=[FeSCN2+eq][Fe3+eq][SCNâˆ’eq]\mathrm{K_c} = \frac{[\mathrm{FeSCN^{2+}}_{eq}]}{[\mathrm{Fe^{3+}}_{eq}][\mathrm{SCN^{-}}_{eq}]} Kcâ€‹=[Fe3+eqâ€‹][SCNâˆ’eqâ€‹][FeSCN2+eqâ€‹]â€‹

Discussion å†™çš„æœ‰ç‚¹ç—›è‹¦

Acid base equilibrium

7A: pH value of strong and weak acid

  • strong acid ionises completely in water
  • weak acid ionises partially in water

7B: buffer solutions

  • buffer solution is made by mixing weak acid with its conjugate base, forming a system of dynamic equilibrium
  • when acid is added, the conjugate base amount is reduce because it accepted the protons,
    • thus the system shifts to right, produce more base, indirectly minimizing pH change
  • when base is added, the weak acid reacts with the hydroxide ions, decreasing in amount
    • thus the system shifts to left, producing more weak acid, indirectly minimizing the pH change
Precautions
  • Careful with dilutions
  • Rinse apparatus before dilute
  • Rinse pH meterâ€™s probe everytime after/before use

This time my brain è¿›æ°´, putting the probe back in its solution everytime after use. I was not supposed to do that. Fortunately, the consequence was small because the solution was a buffer. Thank god everything turned out well, and we got the highest mark for our report in this semester (3.5/3.75) ğŸ˜

Identify unknown organic solvents

Precautions
  • wear masks cuz it stinks, especially the esters
  • be aware when observing effervescence occurence cuz it may occur in an instant then gone

It was fun destroying our noses. Afterwards our class took a group photo. Good times.

entry.title: Derivation of derivative rules
entry.content:
These messy stuff provide simple understanding of how the differentiation formulas are derived, makes memorizing the formulas easier for me, and made me able to derive some of the formulas by myself, which is very useful when you are a forgetful person.

Power rule

Simple expansion of (x + change of x)^n

(x+dx)n=(x+dx)(x+dx)(x+dx)...(x+dx)=xn+nxnâˆ’1dx(x+dx)^n=(x+dx)(x+dx)(x+dx)...(x+dx)\newline=x^n+nx^{n-1}dx (x+dx)n=(x+dx)(x+dx)(x+dx)...(x+dx)=xn+nxnâˆ’1dx

there will be multiples of dx^2 from the expansion but is negligible cause the value of dx^2 is too small
x^n :derived out simply
x^(n-1) :derived as following:

xnâˆ’1dx=(dxâˆ—x...x)+(xâˆ—dx...x)+...(xâˆ—x...dx)x^{n-1}dx=(dx*x...x)+(x*dx...x)+...(x*x...dx) xnâˆ’1dx=(dxâˆ—x...x)+(xâˆ—dx...x)+...(xâˆ—x...dx)

there is n times of (dx * x â€¦* x), thus:

nxnâˆ’1nx^{n-1} nxnâˆ’1

Chain rule

Derivation 1:

ddx[g(h(x))]\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x}[g(h(x))] dxdâ€‹[g(h(x))]

Let h(x) = y

d(g(y))=gâ€²(y)dy\mathrm{d}(g(y))=g'(y) \mathrm{d}y d(g(y))=gâ€²(y)dy

Substitute y with h(x)

gâ€²(y)d(h(x))=gâ€²(h(x))hâ€²(x)dxg'(y) \mathrm{d}(h(x))=g'(h(x))h'(x)\mathrm{d}x gâ€²(y)d(h(x))=gâ€²(h(x))hâ€²(x)dx

Derivation 2:

dzdx=dzdyÃ—dydx\frac{\mathrm {d}z}{\mathrm {d}x}=\frac{\mathrm {d}z}{\mathrm {d}y}\times \frac{\mathrm {d}y}{\mathrm {d}x} dxdzâ€‹=dydzâ€‹Ã—dxdyâ€‹

Other rules involved:

  • Power rule

Product rule

\begin{split} &\frac{\mathrm {d}}{\mathrm {d}x}g(x)h(x)=\lim_{x\rightarrow 0}\frac{g(x+\triangle x)h(x+\triangle x)-g(x)h(x)}{\triangle x}\\ &=\lim_{x\rightarrow 0}\frac{g(x)[h(x+\triangle x)-h(x)]+h(x+\triangle x)[g(x+\triangle x)-g(x)]}{\triangle x}\\ &=\lim_{x\rightarrow 0}\frac{[g(x)h(x+\triangle x)-g(x)h(x+\triangle x)]+g(x+\triangle x)h(x+\triangle x)-g(x)h(x)}{\triangle x}\\ &= (\lim_{\triangle x \rightarrow 0}\frac{g(x)}{\triangle x}\times \lim_{\triangle x \rightarrow 0}\frac{h(x+\triangle x)-h(x)}{\triangle x}) +(\lim_{\triangle x \rightarrow 0}\frac{h(x+\triangle x)}{\triangle x}\times \lim_{\triangle x \rightarrow 0}\frac{g(x+\triangle x)-g(x)}{\triangle x})\\ &=g'(x)h(x)+g(x)h'(x) \end{split}

Geometric illustration:

Other rules involved:

  • First principle

Quotient rule

ddx[g(x)hâˆ’1(x)]=gâ€²(x)hâˆ’1(x)+g(x)[ddxhâˆ’1(x)]=gâ€²(x)h(x)+(âˆ’g(x)hâ€²(x)[h(x)]2)=gâ€²(x)h(x)âˆ’g(x)hâ€²(x)h(x)2\begin{aligned} &\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}[g(x)h^{-1}(x)]\\ &=g'(x)h^{-1}(x)+g(x)[\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}h^{-1}(x)]\\ &=\frac{g'(x)}{h(x)}+(-\frac{g(x)h'(x)}{[h(x)]^2})\\ &=\frac{g'(x)h(x)-g(x)h'(x)}{h(x)^2} \end{aligned} â€‹dxdâ€‹[g(x)hâˆ’1(x)]=gâ€²(x)hâˆ’1(x)+g(x)[dxdâ€‹hâˆ’1(x)]=h(x)gâ€²(x)â€‹+(âˆ’[h(x)]2g(x)hâ€²(x)â€‹)=h(x)2gâ€²(x)h(x)âˆ’g(x)hâ€²(x)â€‹â€‹

Other rules involved:

  • Power rule
  • Reciprocal rule
  • Chain rule

Reciprocal rule

limâ¡hâ†’0(1f(x+h)âˆ’1f(x)h)=limâ¡hâ†’0(f(x)âˆ’f(x+h)hâˆ—f(x)f(x+h))=limâ¡hâ†’0(âˆ’f(x+h)âˆ’f(x)hÃ—1f(x)f(x+h))=âˆ’fâ€²(x)Ã—1f(x)2=âˆ’fâ€²(x)f(x)2\begin{aligned} &\lim_{h\rightarrow0} (\frac{ \frac{1}{f(x+h)} - \frac{1}{f(x)}}{h})\\ &=\lim_{h\rightarrow0}(\frac{f(x)-f(x+h)}{h*f(x)f(x+h)})\\ &=\lim_{h\rightarrow0}(-\frac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{h}\times \frac{1}{f(x)f(x+h)})\\ &=-f'(x)\times \frac{1}{f(x)^2}=-\frac{f'(x)}{f(x)^2} \end{aligned} â€‹hâ†’0limâ€‹(hf(x+h)1â€‹âˆ’f(x)1â€‹â€‹)=hâ†’0limâ€‹(hâˆ—f(x)f(x+h)f(x)âˆ’f(x+h)â€‹)=hâ†’0limâ€‹(âˆ’hf(x+h)âˆ’f(x)â€‹Ã—f(x)f(x+h)1â€‹)=âˆ’fâ€²(x)Ã—f(x)21â€‹=âˆ’f(x)2fâ€²(x)â€‹â€‹

Other rule involved:

  • First principle

Trigonometry derivatives

limâ¡Î¸â†’0sinÎ¸Î¸=1\lim_{\theta \rightarrow 0}\frac{sin \theta}{\theta}=1 Î¸â†’0limâ€‹Î¸sinÎ¸â€‹=1

limâ¡Î¸â†’0cosÎ¸âˆ’1Î¸=0\lim_{\theta \rightarrow 0}\frac{cos \theta-1}{\theta}=0 Î¸â†’0limâ€‹Î¸cosÎ¸âˆ’1â€‹=0

Proof of trig limits

sin

ddx(sinâ¡(x))=limâ¡hâ†’0sinâ¡(x+h)âˆ’sinâ¡xh\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm {d}x}(\sin(x))=\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\frac{\sin(x+h)-\sin x}{h} dxdâ€‹(sin(x))=hâ†’0limâ€‹hsin(x+h)âˆ’sinxâ€‹

From Trig identity: $$\sin(x+h)=\sin(x)\cos(h)+\cos(x)\sin(h)$$

limâ¡hâ†’0sinâ¡(x)cosâ¡(h)+cosâ¡(x)sinâ¡(h)âˆ’sinâ¡(x)h=limâ¡hâ†’0sinâ¡(x)(cosâ¡(h)âˆ’1)+cosâ¡(x)sinâ¡(h)h=limâ¡hâ†’0sinâ¡(x)cosâ¡(h)âˆ’1h+limâ¡hâ†’0cosâ¡(x)sinâ¡(h)h=sinâ¡(x)(0)+cosâ¡(x)(1)=cosâ¡(x)\begin{aligned} &\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\frac{\sin(x)\cos(h)+\cos(x)\sin(h)-\sin(x)}{h}\\ &=\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\frac{\sin(x)(\cos(h)-1)+\cos(x)\sin(h)}{h}\\ &=\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\sin(x)\frac{\cos(h)-1}{h}+\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\cos(x)\frac{\sin(h)}{h}\\ &=\sin(x)(0)+\cos(x)(1)\\ &=\cos(x) \end{aligned} â€‹hâ†’0limâ€‹hsin(x)cos(h)+cos(x)sin(h)âˆ’sin(x)â€‹=hâ†’0limâ€‹hsin(x)(cos(h)âˆ’1)+cos(x)sin(h)â€‹=hâ†’0limâ€‹sin(x)hcos(h)âˆ’1â€‹+hâ†’0limâ€‹cos(x)hsin(h)â€‹=sin(x)(0)+cos(x)(1)=cos(x)â€‹

cos

ddx(cosâ¡(x))=limâ¡hâ†’0cosâ¡(x+h)âˆ’cosâ¡(x)h\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\cos(x))=\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\frac{\cos(x+h)-\cos(x)}{h} dxdâ€‹(cos(x))=hâ†’0limâ€‹hcos(x+h)âˆ’cos(x)â€‹

From [[Trig identity]]:

cosâ¡(x+h)=cosâ¡(x)cosâ¡(h)âˆ’sinâ¡(x)sinâ¡(h)\cos(x+h)=\cos(x)\cos(h)-\sin(x)\sin(h) cos(x+h)=cos(x)cos(h)âˆ’sin(x)sin(h)

limâ¡hâ†’0cosâ¡(x)cosâ¡(h)âˆ’sinâ¡(x)sinâ¡(h)âˆ’cosâ¡(x)h=limâ¡hâ†’0cosâ¡(x)(cosâ¡(h)âˆ’1)âˆ’sinâ¡(x)sinâ¡(h)h=limâ¡hâ†’0cosâ¡(x)cosâ¡(h)âˆ’1hâˆ’limâ¡hâ†’0sinâ¡(x)sinâ¡(h)h=cosâ¡(x)(0)âˆ’sinâ¡(x)(1)=âˆ’sinâ¡(x)\begin{aligned} &\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\frac{\cos(x)\cos(h)-\sin(x)\sin(h)-\cos(x)}{h}\\ &=\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\frac{\cos(x)(\cos(h)-1)-\sin(x)\sin(h)}{h}\\ &=\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\cos(x)\frac{\cos(h)-1}{h}-\lim_{h \rightarrow 0}\frac{\sin(x)\sin(h)}{h}\\ &=\cos(x)(0)-\sin(x)(1)=-\sin(x)\\ \end{aligned} â€‹hâ†’0limâ€‹hcos(x)cos(h)âˆ’sin(x)sin(h)âˆ’cos(x)â€‹=hâ†’0limâ€‹hcos(x)(cos(h)âˆ’1)âˆ’sin(x)sin(h)â€‹=hâ†’0limâ€‹cos(x)hcos(h)âˆ’1â€‹âˆ’hâ†’0limâ€‹hsin(x)sin(h)â€‹=cos(x)(0)âˆ’sin(x)(1)=âˆ’sin(x)â€‹

tan

ddx(tanâ¡(x))=ddx(sinâ¡(x)cosâ¡(x))\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\tan(x))=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\frac{\sin(x)}{\cos(x)}) dxdâ€‹(tan(x))=dxdâ€‹(cos(x)sin(x)â€‹)

From [[Trig identity]]:

cosâ¡2(x)+sinâ¡2(x)=1\cos^2(x)+\sin^2(x)=1 cos2(x)+sin2(x)=1

cosâ¡(x)cosâ¡(x)âˆ’sinâ¡(x)[âˆ’sinâ¡(x)]cosâ¡2(x)=1cosâ¡2(x)=secâ¡2(x)\begin{aligned} &\frac{\cos(x)\cos(x)-\sin(x)[-\sin(x)]}{\cos^2(x)}\\ &=\frac{1}{\cos^2(x)}\\ &=\sec^2(x)\\ \end{aligned} â€‹cos2(x)cos(x)cos(x)âˆ’sin(x)[âˆ’sin(x)]â€‹=cos2(x)1â€‹=sec2(x)â€‹

quotient rule used

cot

ddx(cotâ¡x)=ddx(cosâ¡(x)sinâ¡(x))\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\cot x)=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\frac{\cos(x)}{\sin(x)}) dxdâ€‹(cotx)=dxdâ€‹(sin(x)cos(x)â€‹)

cosâ¡(x)cosâ¡(x)âˆ’[âˆ’sinâ¡(x)sinâ¡(x)]sinâ¡2(x)=1sinâ¡2(x)=cscâ¡2(x)\begin{aligned} &\frac{\cos(x)\cos(x)-[-\sin(x)\sin(x)]}{\sin^2(x)}\\ &=\frac{1}{\sin^2(x)}\\ &=\csc^2(x)\\ \end{aligned} â€‹sin2(x)cos(x)cos(x)âˆ’[âˆ’sin(x)sin(x)]â€‹=sin2(x)1â€‹=csc2(x)â€‹

sec

ddx(secâ¡(x))=ddx(1cosâ¡(x))\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\sec(x))=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\frac{1}{\cos(x)}) dxdâ€‹(sec(x))=dxdâ€‹(cos(x)1â€‹)

âˆ’(âˆ’sinâ¡(x)cosâ¡2(x))=sinâ¡(x)cosâ¡(x)Ã—1cosâ¡(x)=tanâ¡(x)secâ¡(x)\begin{aligned} &-(\frac{-\sin(x)}{\cos^2(x)})\\ &=\frac{\sin(x)}{\cos(x)}\times \frac{1}{\cos(x)}\\ &=\tan(x)\sec(x) \end{aligned} â€‹âˆ’(cos2(x)âˆ’sin(x)â€‹)=cos(x)sin(x)â€‹Ã—cos(x)1â€‹=tan(x)sec(x)â€‹

reciprocal rule used

cosec

ddx(cscâ¡(x))=ddx(1sinâ¡(x))\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\csc(x))=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(\frac{1}{\sin(x)}) dxdâ€‹(csc(x))=dxdâ€‹(sin(x)1â€‹)

âˆ’(cosâ¡(x)sinâ¡2(x))=âˆ’(cosâ¡(x)sinâ¡(x))(1sinâ¡(x))=âˆ’cscâ¡(x)cotâ¡(x)\begin{aligned} &-(\frac{\cos(x)}{\sin^2(x)})\\ &=-(\frac{\cos(x)}{\sin(x)})(\frac{1}{\sin(x)})\\ &=-\csc(x)\cot(x)\\ \end{aligned} â€‹âˆ’(sin2(x)cos(x)â€‹)=âˆ’(sin(x)cos(x)â€‹)(sin(x)1â€‹)=âˆ’csc(x)cot(x)â€‹

reciprocal rule used

entry.title: Basic integrations
entry.content:
Made this around 2023 July. Quick glimpse for basics of integrals for myself before entering uni.

Inverse of derivatives

Integrations are just inverse of derivatives:

ddxâˆ«f(x)dx=f(x)\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\int f(x) \mathrm{d}x=f(x) dxdâ€‹âˆ«f(x)dx=f(x)

Fundamental theorem of calculus

dFdx(x)=f(x)âˆ«abf(x)dx=F(b)âˆ’F(a)\begin{aligned}&\frac{\mathrm{d}F}{\mathrm{d}x}(x)=f(x)\\&\int_{a}^{b} f(x)\mathrm{d}x=F(b)-F(a)\\\end{aligned} â€‹dxdFâ€‹(x)=f(x)âˆ«abâ€‹f(x)dx=F(b)âˆ’F(a)â€‹

Let :

  • f(x) be a continuous real-valued function on a closed interval [a,b]
  • F(x) be a function defined for all x in [a,b]

Definition:

âˆ«abf(x)dx=limâ¡nâ†’âˆâˆ‘i=1nf(xiâˆ—)â–³x\int_{a}^{b}f(x)\mathrm{d}x=\lim_{n\rightarrow \infty}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f(x_{i}^{*})\triangle x âˆ«abâ€‹f(x)dx=nâ†’âˆlimâ€‹i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹f(xiâˆ—â€‹)â–³x

â–³x=bâˆ’an\triangle x=\frac{b-a}{n} â–³x=nbâˆ’aâ€‹

Integral properties

âˆ«f(x)dx=F(x)+c\int f(x)\mathrm{d}x=F(x)+c âˆ«f(x)dx=F(x)+c

âˆ«abf(x)dx=âˆ’âˆ«baf(x)dx\int_{a}^{b}f(x)\mathrm{d}x=-\int_{b}^{a}f(x)\mathrm{d}x âˆ«abâ€‹f(x)dx=âˆ’âˆ«baâ€‹f(x)dx

âˆ«abf(x)Â±g(x)dx=âˆ«abf(x)dxÂ±âˆ«abg(x)dx\int_{a}^{b}f(x)\pm g(x)\mathrm{d}x=\int_{a}^{b}f(x)\mathrm{d}x\pm \int_{a}^{b}g(x)\mathrm{d}x âˆ«abâ€‹f(x)Â±g(x)dx=âˆ«abâ€‹f(x)dxÂ±âˆ«abâ€‹g(x)dx

âˆ«abf(x)dx+âˆ«bcf(x)dx=âˆ«acf(x)dx\int_{a}^{b}f(x)\mathrm{d}x+\int_{b}^{c}f(x)\mathrm{d}x=\int_{a}^{c}f(x)\mathrm{d}x âˆ«abâ€‹f(x)dx+âˆ«bcâ€‹f(x)dx=âˆ«acâ€‹f(x)dx

âˆ«abcdx=c(bâˆ’a)\int_{a}^{b}c\mathrm{d}x=c(b-a) âˆ«abâ€‹cdx=c(bâˆ’a)

Common integrals

Integrals â—
$$\int x^n\mathrm{d}x=\frac{x^{n+1}}{n+1}+c$$ $$\int \sec^2x\mathrm{d}x=\tan x +c$$
$$\int x^{-1}\mathrm{d}x=\ln \mid x\mid + c$$ $$\int \sec x \tan x \mathrm{d}x=\sec x +c$$
$$\int \frac{1}{ax+b}\mathrm{d}x=\frac{1}{a}\ln \mid ax+b\mid +c$$ $$\int \csc x \cot x \mathrm{d}x=-\csc x +c$$
$$\int \ln(x)\mathrm{d}x=x\ln(x)-x+c$$ $$\int \csc^2x\mathrm{d}x=-\cot x +c$$
$$\int e^x \mathrm{d}x=e^x+c$$ $$\int\tan x \mathrm{d}x=\ln \mid \sec x \mid +c$$
$$\int \cos x \mathrm{d}x=\sin x +c$$ $$\int \sec x \mathrm{d}x=\ln \mid \sec x +\tan x \mid +c$$
$$\int\sin x \mathrm{d}x=-\cos x +c$$ $$\int \frac{1}{a^2 + u^2}\mathrm{d}x=\frac{1}{a}\tan^{-1}(\frac{u}{a})+c$$
$$\int \frac{1}{\sqrt{a^2-u^2}}\mathrm{d}x=\sin^{-1}(\frac{u}{a})+c$$ $$\int k \mathrm{d}x=kx +c$$
$$\int \csc x \mathrm{d}x=-\ln \mid \csc x + \cot x \mid +c$$ $$\int \sec x \mathrm{d}x=\ln \mid \sec x + \tan x \mid +c$$
$$ \int \tan x \mathrm{d}x = -\ln \mid \cos x \mid +c$$ $$\int \cot x\mathrm{d}x=\ln \sin x +c$$

entry.title: Linear algebra basics
entry.content:
Had an awesome visual learning experience from 3blue1brown, which made me finished this topic in days. Havenâ€™t had such compelling learning experience in months that I was even studying at a saloon while waiting for my mother to cleanse her face for two hours and come out with no visible improvement.
First and foremost, the fundamental concept, which is vector, must be clear.

Vector

  • Lines with magnitude and direction (arrow) in space
  • Where the magnitude and direction can be represented with matrixes
    E.g. (2D space)

[xy]\begin{bmatrix}x\\ y \end{bmatrix}[xyâ€‹]

x represents the steps taken along x-axis and y represents steps taken along y-axis
And so on: (3D space)

[xyz]\begin{bmatrix} x\\ y\\ z \end{bmatrix}â£â¢â¡â€‹xyzâ€‹â¦â¥â¤â€‹

The principle of vectorsâ€™ addition and simple multiplication with constant (scalar multiplication) are straightforward, just motions added together and scaled, thus omitted.

Span

The set of all linear combination (column space) of given vectors.

avâ†’+bwâ†’,a,bâˆˆRa\overrightarrow{v} + b\overrightarrow{w}, \hspace{0.5in} a,b \in \mathbb{R} av+bw,a,bâˆˆR

When there are multiple vectors, and one can be removed without reducing the span, the vectors are called linearly dependent, one of the vecotr can be expressed as the scaled/transformed version of the other.
When each vectors among a set of vetors all increases/decreases the span when added/removed, they are called linearly independent.

Basis vectors

A set of linearly independent vectors.
Usually represented as $$\hat\imath \hspace{0.1in} and \hspace{0.1in}\hat\jmath$$

Linear transformation

Concept

Basically pass input vector into some functions to produce output vector Â¯_(ãƒ„)_/Â¯, by transforming (shaping) the space grids
Characteristics of linear transformation:

  • lines remain straight
  • origin stays fixed
  • grid lines remain parallel and evenly spaced
  • preserve additivity and scaling

The (2D) transformation can be described in 2x2 matrix:

[xÄ±^xÈ·^yÄ±^yÈ·^]\begin{bmatrix} x_{\hat\imath} & x_{\hat\jmath}\\ y_{\hat\imath} & y_{\hat\jmath} \end{bmatrix} [xÄ±^â€‹yÄ±^â€‹â€‹xÈ·^â€‹â€‹yÈ·^â€‹â€‹â€‹]

Notable that the matrix is defined by place of Ã® and Äµ after the transformation.

Applying the transformation to a vector:

[abcd][xy]=x[ac]+y[bd]=[ax+bycx+dy]\begin{bmatrix} a & b\\ c & d \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} x\\ y \end{bmatrix}=x\begin{bmatrix} a\\ c \end{bmatrix}+y\begin{bmatrix} b\\ d \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} ax+by\\ cx+dy \end{bmatrix}[acâ€‹bdâ€‹][xyâ€‹]=x[acâ€‹]+y[bdâ€‹]=[ax+bycx+dyâ€‹]

Notice that it is just multiplying vector by the place where Ã® and Äµ lands, according to x and y-axis respectively.

With that concept in mind, the 3D linear transformation would look like this:

[xi^xj^xk^yi^yj^yk^zi^zj^zk^][xyz]\begin{bmatrix} x_{\widehat{i}} & x_{\widehat{j}} & x_{\widehat{k}}\\ y_{\widehat{i}} & y_{\widehat{j}} & y_{\widehat{k}}\\ z_{\widehat{i}} & z_{\widehat{j}} & z_{\widehat{k}} \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} x\\ y\\ z \end{bmatrix}â£â¢â¡â€‹xiâ€‹yiâ€‹ziâ€‹â€‹xjâ€‹â€‹yjâ€‹â€‹zjâ€‹â€‹â€‹xkâ€‹ykâ€‹zkâ€‹â€‹â¦â¥â¤â€‹â£â¢â¡â€‹xyzâ€‹â¦â¥â¤â€‹

Cool stuff: when multiplying a vector by a linearly dependent column, the span dimension will be reduced (2D to 1D). This is called rank 1 tranformation.
Note: rank is the dimension of tranformation output, rank 1 for 1D and rank 2 for 2D and so on. Full rank means the dimesion is unchanged, lowered rank comes with null space or kernel (lines of vectors squished onto the origin).

Combining matrixes

To combine and sum up transformation, we multiply them, where order of transformation is arranged from right to left, because the right transformation occurred first, then the Ã® and Äµ are transformed again, with a matrix multiplied on its left side:

[abcd][efgh]=[abcd][eg]+[abcd][fh]=[ae+bgaf+bhce+dgcf+dh]\begin{bmatrix} a & b\\ c & d \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} e & f\\ g & h \end{bmatrix}= \begin{bmatrix} a & b\\ c & d \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} e\\ g \end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix} a & b\\ c & d \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} f\\ h \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} ae+bg & af+bh\\ ce+dg & cf+dh \end{bmatrix}[acâ€‹bdâ€‹][egâ€‹fhâ€‹]=[acâ€‹bdâ€‹][egâ€‹]+[acâ€‹bdâ€‹][fhâ€‹]=[ae+bgce+dgâ€‹af+bhcf+dhâ€‹]

Changing basis vectors

Imagine a different coordinate system with a-hat and b-hat as its basis vectors, which when compared to the standard coordinate system would be some random vector unaligned with Ã® and Äµ. To translate a certain vector from our coordinate system to their coordinate system would look like this:

[abcd]âˆ’1vâ†’\begin{bmatrix} a & b\\ c & d \end{bmatrix}^{-1}\overrightarrow{v} [acâ€‹bdâ€‹]âˆ’1v

It is just the inverse of basis matrix transformation (from ours to theirs inversed become theirs to ours) applied onto the vector (which is expressed in our coordinate system). This transforms the grids space from theirs to ours, and the vector expressed in our language to theirs. This is because the original basis vectors transformation matrix represents their basis vectors being translated to our language. Thus when inversed, it becomes the opposite, expressing our vectors in their language. Similarly to see how a vector written in their language in represented in our language, we apply the non-inversed basis vector transformation matrix to their language. A bit confusing yes.
Translation of transformation (from our language to theirs):

[acbd][prqs][acbd]âˆ’1\begin{bmatrix} a & c\\ b & d \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} p & r\\ q & s \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} a & c\\ b & d \end{bmatrix}^{-1} [abâ€‹cdâ€‹][pqâ€‹rsâ€‹][abâ€‹cdâ€‹]âˆ’1

Determinants, |A|

Represents the scalar multiplication factor/scalar value of an area in a transformation
Basically use it to calculate how much an area scale up or down after a transformation:

2D:det([abcd])=adâˆ’bc\mathrm{2D: \hspace{0.5in} det}(\begin{bmatrix} a & b\\ c & d \end{bmatrix})=ad-bc 2D:det([acâ€‹bdâ€‹])=adâˆ’bc

3D:det([abcdefghi])=adet([efhi])âˆ’bdet([dfgi])+cdet([degh])\mathrm{3D:\hspace{0.5in}det}(\begin{bmatrix} {\color{Red} a} & {\color{Blue} b} & {\color{Teal} c}\\ d & e & f\\ g & h & i \end{bmatrix})={\color{Red} a}\mathrm{det}(\begin{bmatrix} e & f\\ h & i \end{bmatrix})-{\color{Blue} b}\mathrm{det}(\begin{bmatrix} d & f\\ g & i \end{bmatrix})+{\color{Teal} c}\mathrm{det}(\begin{bmatrix} d & e\\ g & h \end{bmatrix}) 3D:det(â£â¢â¡â€‹adgâ€‹behâ€‹cfiâ€‹â¦â¥â¤â€‹)=adet([ehâ€‹fiâ€‹])âˆ’bdet([dgâ€‹fiâ€‹])+cdet([dgâ€‹ehâ€‹])

The computations are geometrically easier to understand, but troublesome, thus omitted here.

Inverse matrixes

Reverse the linear transformation. Basically the same concept as inverse functions, but is useful to think of as visual transformations.

[abcd]âˆ’1=1adâˆ’bc[dâˆ’bâˆ’ca]\begin{bmatrix} a & b\\ c & d \end{bmatrix}^{-1}=\frac{1}{ad-bc}\begin{bmatrix} d & -b\\ -c & a \end{bmatrix} [acâ€‹bdâ€‹]âˆ’1=adâˆ’bc1â€‹[dâˆ’câ€‹âˆ’baâ€‹]

The computations are kind of a hustle so ya omitted.

Non-square matrixes

With the same concept of what matrix represents in mind, the non-square matrixes can be interpreted as transformation to lower or higher dimensions, for example, this lower the rank to rank 2 as we notice the disappearance of z-axis coordinate in the transformation:

[abcdef][xyz]\begin{bmatrix} a & b & c\\ d & e & f \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x\\ y\\ z \end{bmatrix} [adâ€‹beâ€‹cfâ€‹]â£â¢â¡â€‹xyzâ€‹â¦â¥â¤â€‹

Dot products

[ab]â€¢[cd]=ac+bd\begin{bmatrix} a\\ b \end{bmatrix} â€¢ \begin{bmatrix} c\\ d \end{bmatrix} =a c + b d [abâ€‹]â€¢[cdâ€‹]=ac+bd

Really cool stuff going on involving duality, hard to explain by words so here is a link to 3blue1brownâ€™s video:
From my understanding, it is the product of length of projected vector A onto vector B times length of vector B. It is somehow the same as 2x1 matrix transformation where the rank 1 transformation takes place (2D to 1D). This interchangeability is due to the fact that the basis vectors, when transformed via the 2x1 matrix, results in coordinates same as the vector_1 on the 1D number line they were projected to. This means the transformation on vector_2 (by multiplying by the 2x1 matrix) would result in the projection of it on the 1D number line that vector_1 is on. Therefore the second way of interpreting the dot product came out to be interpreting one of the vector as a (2x1) matrix although it is just 1x2, because of the correspondence characteristic of it. The computational result of matrix-vector product and dot product happens to be the same!

[ab][cd]=ac+bd\begin{bmatrix} a & b \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} c\\ d \end{bmatrix} =a c + b d [aâ€‹bâ€‹][cdâ€‹]=ac+bd

[ab]â€¢[cd]â‡”[ab][cd]\begin{bmatrix} a\\ b \end{bmatrix} â€¢ \begin{bmatrix} c\\ d \end{bmatrix} \hspace{0.3in}\Leftrightarrow \hspace{0.3in} \begin{bmatrix} a & b \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} c\\ d \end{bmatrix} [abâ€‹]â€¢[cdâ€‹]â‡”[aâ€‹bâ€‹][cdâ€‹]

Dot product is useful in testing if the vectors are in similar directions or not (by looking at the positive negative value).

Cross product

The cross product is technically a new vector in a 3D space, where the length of the vector is equal to the determinant of the vectors.

[ac]Ã—[bd]=det([abcd])\begin{bmatrix} a\\ c \end{bmatrix}\times \begin{bmatrix} b\\ d \end{bmatrix}=\mathrm{det}( \begin{bmatrix} a & b\\ c & d \end{bmatrix}) [acâ€‹]Ã—[bdâ€‹]=det([acâ€‹bdâ€‹])

Note: it is important to think of the product as a vector and not parallelepiped volume. For deeper understanding, watch another 3blue1brown video:
From my understanding, we are basically finding the dual vector that when transforming with another given vector (3x1), gives the same result as the determinant of the given vector with another two constant vectors. The dual vector concept comes from the duality mentioned in dot products, where in this case is interpreted as the â€œdual vectorâ€ we are finding projected onto a line perpendicular to the parallelogram plane formed by the other two constant vectors. Notational trick is also taught in the video but I want to understand it geometrically (which Iâ€™m still trying to).

Cramerâ€™s Rule

This is to determine the original vector when given a transformed vector along with its transformation matrix (A). Imagine two parallelograms, formed by Ã® and Äµ vectors with a same vector X respectively. Their areas would be:

withÄ±^:1Ã—y=ywithÈ·^:1Ã—x=x\begin{aligned}\mathrm{with \hspace{0.1in}\hat\imath:\hspace{0.2in}}1\times y=y \\ \mathrm{with \hspace{0.1in}\hat\jmath:\hspace{0.2in}}1\times x=x \\ \end{aligned} withÄ±^:1Ã—y=ywithÈ·^â€‹:1Ã—x=xâ€‹

After the transformation, the parallelogram areas will be scaled up:

Areaaftertransfomration(Ä±^)=yÃ—det(A)Areaaftertransfomration(È·^)=xÃ—det(A)\begin{aligned} \mathrm{Area \hspace{0.05in}after\hspace{0.05in}transfomration\hspace{0.05in}(\hat\imath)}=y\times \mathrm{det(A)} \\ \mathrm{Area \hspace{0.05in}after\hspace{0.05in}transfomration\hspace{0.05in}(\hat\jmath)}=x\times \mathrm{det(A)}\end{aligned} Areaaftertransfomration(Ä±^)=yÃ—det(A)Areaaftertransfomration(È·^â€‹)=xÃ—det(A)â€‹

Thus derived:

x/yori=Areaaftertransformationdet(A)x/y_{ori}=\frac{\mathrm{Area\hspace{0.05in}after\hspace{0.05in}transformation}}{\mathrm{det(A)}} x/yoriâ€‹=det(A)Areaaftertransformationâ€‹

The area after the transformation can be found by arranging a 2x2 matrix with the transformed vector X with the corresponding basis vector transformation, then finding its determinant. This same concept applies to higher rank transformations, just with volumes and 3x3 matrixes and extra basis vectors ğŸ‘

Eigenvectors

Eigenvectors are vectors that remain on the same line of span after a linear transformation. To find eigenvectors, we first find the eigenvalues, which we can do by arranging the following equation:

Avâ†’=Î»vâ†’(Aâˆ’Î»)vâ†’=0Î»=[Î»00Î»]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{A}\overrightarrow{v}=\lambda\overrightarrow{v} \\(A-\lambda)\overrightarrow{v}=0 \\ \lambda= \begin{bmatrix} \lambda & 0 \\ 0 & \lambda \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned} Av=Î»v(Aâˆ’Î»)v=0Î»=[Î»0â€‹0Î»â€‹]â€‹

A represents linear transformation matrix, lambda represents eigenvalues, which is the scalar of the vector after linear transformation. This is true because for eigenvectors, the before and after are of the same except scaled differently. So solving for det(A-Î»)=0 we can find the eigenvalues ğŸ‘This is because we know that the only when the transformation is lowered in rank (determinant = 0), then the result of transforming a non-zero vector would be zero.
To find the eigenvector, simply sub the Î» back:

[aâˆ’Î»bcdâˆ’Î»][xy]=[00]\begin{bmatrix} a-\lambda & b\\ c & d-\lambda \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} [aâˆ’Î»câ€‹bdâˆ’Î»â€‹][xyâ€‹]=[00â€‹]

Shortcut for computing eigenvalues

[abcd]Î»1,Î»2=mÂ±m2âˆ’pm=a+d2p=adâˆ’bc\begin{aligned}&\begin{bmatrix} a & b\\ c & d \end{bmatrix}\\& \lambda_1,\hspace{0.02in}\lambda_2 = m Â± \sqrt{m^2 - p}\\& m= \frac{a+d}{2} \\& p=ad-bc\end{aligned} â€‹[acâ€‹bdâ€‹]Î»1â€‹,Î»2â€‹=mÂ±m2âˆ’pâ€‹m=2a+dâ€‹p=adâˆ’bcâ€‹

Eigenbasis

After finding out the eigenvectors, we can form a change of basis matrix. The reason to do so is because the math operations with eigenbasis can be a lot more easier, since they always come in such form:

[a00b]\begin{bmatrix} a & 0 \\ 0 & b \end{bmatrix} [a0â€‹0bâ€‹]

Then we just translate our want-to-be-computed vectors to this eigenbasis language, compute it, then translate back again.

entry.title: Standard integration techniques
entry.content:
Tips: factorize/ expand/ simplify the equation beforehand, and get creative

Substitution

âˆ«abf(g(x))gâ€²(x)dx=âˆ«g(a)g(b)f(u)du\int_{a}^{b}f(g(x))g'(x)\mathrm{d}x=\int_{g(a)}^{g(b)}f(u)\mathrm{d}u âˆ«abâ€‹f(g(x))gâ€²(x)dx=âˆ«g(a)g(b)â€‹f(u)du

  • u = g(x)
  • du = gâ€™(x)dx
Example:

âˆ«125x2cosâ¡(x3)dx=âˆ«1853cosâ¡(u)du=[53sinâ¡(u)]18=53(sinâ¡(8)âˆ’sinâ¡(1))\begin{aligned}&\int_{1}^{2}5x^2\cos(x^3)\mathrm{d}x\\&=\int_{1}^{8}\frac{5}{3}\cos(u)\mathrm{d}u\\&=[\frac{5}{3}\sin(u)]_{1}^{8}\\&=\frac{5}{3}(\sin(8)-\sin(1))\end{aligned} â€‹âˆ«12â€‹5x2cos(x3)dx=âˆ«18â€‹35â€‹cos(u)du=[35â€‹sin(u)]18â€‹=35â€‹(sin(8)âˆ’sin(1))â€‹

  • u = x^3
  • du = 3x^2 dx
  • x^2 dx = 1/3 du

Integration by parts

âˆ«abudv=[uv]abâˆ’âˆ«abvdu\int_{a}^{b} u \mathrm{d}v =[uv]_{a}^{b} - \int_{a}^{b} v \mathrm{d}u âˆ«abâ€‹udv=[uv]abâ€‹âˆ’âˆ«abâ€‹vdu

  • choose u and dv
  • compute du with differentiation
  • compute v with integration
  • generally put more complicated shit as dv and easier shit as u
    Derivation of integration by parts:
    Product rule states that: $$\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}uv = v\frac{\mathrm{d}u}{\mathrm{d}x} \times u\frac{\mathrm{d}v}{\mathrm{d}x}$$
    Thus: $$\mathrm{d}(uv)=v\mathrm{d}u \times u\mathrm{d}v$$
    Integrate both sides: $$\int \mathrm{d}(uv) = \int v\mathrm{d}u \times \int u\mathrm{d}v=uv$$

âˆ«udv=uvâˆ’âˆ«vdu\int u\mathrm{d}v=uv-\int v\mathrm{d}u âˆ«udv=uvâˆ’âˆ«vdu

Example:

âˆ«35lnâ¡(x)dx=[xlnâ¡(x)]35âˆ’âˆ«35xxdx=[xlnâ¡(x)âˆ’x]35=5lnâ¡(5)âˆ’3lnâ¡(3)âˆ’2\begin{aligned}&\int_{3}^{5}\ln (x)\mathrm{d}x\\&=[x\ln(x)]_{3}^{5}-\int_{3}^{5}\frac{x}{x}\mathrm{d}x\\&=[x\ln (x)-x]_{3}^{5}\\&=5\ln(5)-3\ln(3)-2\end{aligned} â€‹âˆ«35â€‹ln(x)dx=[xln(x)]35â€‹âˆ’âˆ«35â€‹xxâ€‹dx=[xln(x)âˆ’x]35â€‹=5ln(5)âˆ’3ln(3)âˆ’2â€‹

  • u = ln(x)
  • dv = dx
  • du = 1/x dx
  • v = x

Trig substitution

a2âˆ’b2x2â†’x=absinâ¡(Î¸)cosâ¡2(Î¸)=1âˆ’sinâ¡2(Î¸)b2x2âˆ’a2â†’x=absecâ¡(Î¸)tanâ¡2(Î¸)=secâ¡2(Î¸)âˆ’1a2+b2x2â†’x=abtanâ¡(Î¸)sec2(Î¸)=1+tanâ¡2(Î¸)\begin{aligned}\sqrt{a^2-b^2x^2}\rightarrow x=\frac{a}{b}\sin(\theta)\\&\cos^2(\theta)=1-\sin^2(\theta)\\\sqrt{b^2x^2-a^2}\rightarrow x=\frac{a}{b}\sec(\theta)\\&\tan^2(\theta)=\sec^2(\theta)-1\\\sqrt{a^2+b^2x^2} \rightarrow x=\frac{a}{b}\tan(\theta)\\&sec^2(\theta)=1+\tan^2(\theta)\end{aligned} a2âˆ’b2x2â€‹â†’x=baâ€‹sin(Î¸)b2x2âˆ’a2â€‹â†’x=baâ€‹sec(Î¸)a2+b2x2â€‹â†’x=baâ€‹tan(Î¸)â€‹cos2(Î¸)=1âˆ’sin2(Î¸)tan2(Î¸)=sec2(Î¸)âˆ’1sec2(Î¸)=1+tan2(Î¸)â€‹

If integral contains the roots above, apply substitution to convert it into trig functions

Example:

âˆ«16x24âˆ’9x2dx=âˆ«16x222âˆ’32(x2)dxx=23sinâ¡(Î¸)â†’dx=23cosâ¡(Î¸)dÎ¸4âˆ’9x2=4âˆ’4sinâ¡2(Î¸)=4cosâ¡2(Î¸)=2âˆ£cosâ¡(Î¸)âˆ£âˆ«1649sinâ¡2(Î¸)(2cosâ¡Î¸)(23cosâ¡Î¸)dÎ¸=âˆ«12sinâ¡2(Î¸)dÎ¸=âˆ«12cscâ¡2(Î¸)dÎ¸=âˆ’12cotâ¡(Î¸)+c\begin{aligned}&\int \frac{16}{x^2\sqrt{4-9x^2}}\mathrm{d}x \\& =\int \frac{16}{x^2\sqrt{2^2-3^2(x^2)}} \mathrm{d}x\\& x=\frac{2}{3}\sin(\theta) \rightarrow \mathrm{d}x=\frac{2}{3}\cos(\theta)\mathrm{d}\theta \\& \sqrt{4-9x^2}=\sqrt{4-4\sin^2(\theta)}=\sqrt{4\cos^2(\theta)}=2\mid \cos(\theta) \mid \\& \int \frac{16}{\frac{4}{9}\sin^2(\theta)(2\cos\theta)}(\frac{2}{3}\cos\theta)\mathrm{d}\theta\\&=\int \frac{12}{\sin^2(\theta)}\mathrm{d}\theta\\&=\int 12\csc^2(\theta)\mathrm{d}\theta\\&=-12\cot(\theta)+c\\\end{aligned} â€‹âˆ«x24âˆ’9x2â€‹16â€‹dx=âˆ«x222âˆ’32(x2)â€‹16â€‹dxx=32â€‹sin(Î¸)â†’dx=32â€‹cos(Î¸)dÎ¸4âˆ’9x2â€‹=4âˆ’4sin2(Î¸)â€‹=4cos2(Î¸)â€‹=2âˆ£cos(Î¸)âˆ£âˆ«94â€‹sin2(Î¸)(2cosÎ¸)16â€‹(32â€‹cosÎ¸)dÎ¸=âˆ«sin2(Î¸)12â€‹dÎ¸=âˆ«12csc2(Î¸)dÎ¸=âˆ’12cot(Î¸)+câ€‹

Partial fractions

Example:

âˆ«7x2+13x(xâˆ’1)(x2+4)dx7x2+13x(xâˆ’1)(x2+4)=Axâˆ’1+Bx+Cx2+4=A(x2+4)+(Bx+C)(xâˆ’1)(xâˆ’1)(x2+4)7x2+13x=(A+B)x2+(Câˆ’B)x+4Aâˆ’CA=4;B=3;C=16Substituteback:âˆ«4xâˆ’1+3x+16x2+4dx=âˆ«4xâˆ’1+3xx2+4+16x2+4dx\begin{aligned}&\int \frac{7x^2+13x}{(x-1)(x^2+4)}\mathrm{d}x \\& \frac{7x^2+13x}{(x-1)(x^2+4)}=\frac{A}{x-1}+\frac{Bx+C}{x^2+4} \\& = \frac{A(x^2+4)+(Bx+C)(x-1)}{(x-1)(x^2+4)} \\& 7x^2+13x=(A+B)x^2+(C-B)x+4A-C \\& A=4; B=3; C=16 \\& \\& \mathrm{Substitute \hspace{0.05in} back:} \\& \int \frac{4}{x-1}+\frac{3x+16}{x^2+4}\mathrm{d}x \\& = \int \frac{4}{x-1}+\frac{3x}{x^2+4}+\frac{16}{x^2+4}\mathrm{d}x \end{aligned} â€‹âˆ«(xâˆ’1)(x2+4)7x2+13xâ€‹dx(xâˆ’1)(x2+4)7x2+13xâ€‹=xâˆ’1Aâ€‹+x2+4Bx+Câ€‹=(xâˆ’1)(x2+4)A(x2+4)+(Bx+C)(xâˆ’1)â€‹7x2+13x=(A+B)x2+(Câˆ’B)x+4Aâˆ’CA=4;B=3;C=16Substituteback:âˆ«xâˆ’14â€‹+x2+43x+16â€‹dx=âˆ«xâˆ’14â€‹+x2+43xâ€‹+x2+416â€‹dxâ€‹

entry.title: Circular motion basics
entry.content:
Polar coordinates


The basis vectors of polar coordinates are represented as

r^andÎ¸^0â‰¤râ‰¤âˆ0â‰¤Î¸â‰¤2Ï€\begin{aligned} \hat{r} \hspace{0.1in} \mathrm{and} \hspace{0.1in}\hat\theta \\ \\ 0 â‰¤ r â‰¤ âˆ \\ 0 â‰¤ Î¸ â‰¤ 2Ï€ \end{aligned}r^andÎ¸^0â‰¤râ‰¤âˆ0â‰¤Î¸â‰¤2Ï€â€‹


r-hat and Î¸-hat are changing along with the coordinates, thus is represented as a function, in terms of i-hat, j-hat and Î¸ (note: basis vectors have magnitude of 1):

r^=cosâ¡Î¸Ä±^+sinâ¡Î¸È·^Î¸^=âˆ’sinâ¡Î¸Ä±^+cosâ¡Î¸È·^\begin{aligned} \\& \hat{r} = \cos\theta \hspace{0.05in} \hat\imath + \sin\theta \hspace{0.05in} \hat\jmath \\& \hat\theta = -\sin\theta \hspace{0.05in} \hat\imath + \cos\theta \hspace{0.05in} \hat\jmath \end{aligned}â€‹r^=cosÎ¸Ä±^+sinÎ¸È·^â€‹Î¸^=âˆ’sinÎ¸Ä±^+cosÎ¸È·^â€‹â€‹

Position vector

From the graph we know that the r and the theta are time dependent, thus the position vector, can be represented a length, r, times the direction it is pointing towards, which is r-hat:

râƒ—(t)=rr^(t)=rcosâ¡Î¸(t)Ä±^+rsinâ¡Î¸(t)È·^\begin{aligned} \\& \vec{r}(t) \\&= r \hspace{0.05in} \hat{r}(t) \\& = r\cos\theta(t) \hspace{0.05in} \hat\imath + r\sin\theta(t) \hspace{0.05in} \hat\jmath \end{aligned}â€‹r(t)=rr^(t)=rcosÎ¸(t)Ä±^+rsinÎ¸(t)È·^â€‹â€‹

The tangential unit vector isnâ€™t included because it is perpendicular to the vector and doesnâ€™t contribute to the vector component. Imagine a vector in a normal Cartesian plane pointing upwards, perpendicular to the x-axis: that vectorâ€™s i-hat component is zero. Same concept applies here.

Velocity vector

Tangential velocity

vâƒ—=drâƒ—dt=r(âˆ’sinâ¡Î¸(t)dÎ¸dtÄ±^+cosâ¡Î¸(t)dÎ¸dtÈ·^)=rdÎ¸dt(âˆ’sinâ¡Î¸(t)Ä±^+cosâ¡Î¸(t)È·^)=rdÎ¸dtÎ¸^\begin{aligned} \\ & \vec{v} =\frac{\mathrm{d}\vec{r}}{\mathrm{d}t} \\ & = r(-\sin\theta(t)\frac{\mathrm{d}\theta}{\mathrm{d}t}\hspace{0.05in} \hat\imath+\cos\theta(t)\frac{\mathrm{d}\theta}{\mathrm{d}t}\hspace{0.05in} \hat\jmath) \\ & = r\frac{\mathrm{d}\theta}{\mathrm{d}t}(-\sin\theta(t)\hspace{0.05in} \hat\imath+\cos\theta(t)\hspace{0.05in} \hat\jmath) \\ & = r\frac{\mathrm{d}\theta}{\mathrm{d}t}\hspace{0.05in}\hat\theta \end{aligned}â€‹v=dtdrâ€‹=r(âˆ’sinÎ¸(t)dtdÎ¸â€‹Ä±^+cosÎ¸(t)dtdÎ¸â€‹È·^â€‹)=rdtdÎ¸â€‹(âˆ’sinÎ¸(t)Ä±^+cosÎ¸(t)È·^â€‹)=rdtdÎ¸â€‹Î¸^â€‹

It is derived that the velocity is tangential in direction of theta-hat (tangential).

Angular velocity

But there is another direction of velocity which is perpendicular to the direction of rotation (in or out of the plane), known as angular velocity:

Ï‰âƒ—=dÎ¸dtk^\vec\omega=\frac{\mathrm{d}\theta}{\mathrm{d}t}\hspace{0.05in}\hat{k} Ï‰=dtdÎ¸â€‹k^

dÎ¸dt=Ï‰z\frac{\mathrm{d}\theta}{\mathrm{d}t}=\omega_z dtdÎ¸â€‹=Ï‰zâ€‹

The k-hat defines if the angular velocity is pointing out of the plan (âŠ™), or into the plane (âŠ—). The direction can be defined using right-hand rule.

Angular velocity will have units of radians/s, and angular acceleration will have units of radians/s2. If we multiply these by a distance, such asÂ r, the units will be m, m/s, or m/s2.
linear velocity (v) is equal to the product of the radial distance Â® and the angular velocity (Ï‰)

Angular frequency

It is essentially the same concept as angular velocity (rad/s), but it is used for waves and oscillations while angular velocity is used for circular motions. It is also denoted as Ï‰:

Ï‰=2Ï€T=2Ï€f\omega=\frac{2\pi}{T}=2\pi f Ï‰=T2Ï€â€‹=2Ï€f

Acceleration vector

Centripetal force


Note that both circle above are for the same event, thus we know that both vector r and vector v takes the same time to make a full rotation:

T1=2Ï€rvT2=2Ï€vaT1=T22Ï€rv=2Ï€vaa=v2r\begin{aligned} \\ & T_1=\frac{2\pi r}{v} \\ & T_2=\frac{2\pi v}{a} \\ & T_1 = T_2 \\ & \frac{2\pi r}{v}=\frac{2\pi v}{a} \\ & a = \frac{v^2}{r} \end{aligned}â€‹T1â€‹=v2Ï€râ€‹T2â€‹=a2Ï€vâ€‹T1â€‹=T2â€‹v2Ï€râ€‹=a2Ï€vâ€‹a=rv2â€‹â€‹

Uniform circular motion

The rate of change of theta is constant, thus thee radial acceleration is directly the derivative of the previous tangential velocity vector, with the tangential component as a constant:

aâƒ—=dvâƒ—dt=ddt(rdÎ¸dt)Î¸^=rdÎ¸dt(âˆ’cosâ¡Î¸(t)dÎ¸dtÄ±^âˆ’sinâ¡Î¸(t)dÎ¸dtÈ·^)=âˆ’r(dÎ¸dt)2r^\begin{aligned} \\ & \vec{a} = \frac{\mathrm{d}\vec{v}}{\mathrm{d}t} \\& = \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}(r \frac{\mathrm{d}\theta}{\mathrm{d}t})\hat\theta \\ & = r \hspace{0.05in} \frac{\mathrm{d}\theta}{\mathrm{d}t} \hspace{0.05in} (-\cos\theta(t)\frac{\mathrm{d}\theta}{\mathrm{d}t} \hspace{0.05in} \hat\imath-\sin\theta(t)\frac{\mathrm{d}\theta}{\mathrm{d}t} \hspace{0.05in} \hat\jmath) \\ & = -r \hspace{0.05in} (\frac{\mathrm{d}\theta}{\mathrm{d}t})^2 \hspace{0.05in} \hat{r} \end{aligned}â€‹a=dtdvâ€‹=dtdâ€‹(rdtdÎ¸â€‹)Î¸^=rdtdÎ¸â€‹(âˆ’cosÎ¸(t)dtdÎ¸â€‹Ä±^âˆ’sinÎ¸(t)dtdÎ¸â€‹È·^â€‹)=âˆ’r(dtdÎ¸â€‹)2r^â€‹

Through this we can see that the direction of radial acceleration, is against r-hat, meaning it is directed inwards.

Non-uniform circular motion

aâƒ—=dvâƒ—dt=ddt(rdÎ¸dt)Î¸^+(rdÎ¸dt)Î¸^=rd2Î¸dt2Î¸^âˆ’r(dÎ¸dt)2r^=Î±Î¸Î¸^+Î±rr^\begin{aligned} \\ & \vec{a} = \frac{\mathrm{d}\vec{v}}{\mathrm{d}t} \\ & = \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}(r \frac{\mathrm{d}\theta}{\mathrm{d}t})\hat\theta + (r \frac{\mathrm{d}\theta}{\mathrm{d}t})\hat\theta \\ & = r \hspace{0.05in} \frac{\mathrm{d^2}\theta}{\mathrm{d}t^2} \hspace{0.05in} \hat\theta -r \hspace{0.05in} (\frac{\mathrm{d}\theta}{\mathrm{d}t})^2 \hspace{0.05in} \hat{r} \\ & = \alpha_\theta\hspace{0.05in} \hat{\theta}\hspace{0.07in}+\hspace{0.07in}\alpha_r\hspace{0.05in}\hat{r} \end{aligned}â€‹a=dtdvâ€‹=dtdâ€‹(rdtdÎ¸â€‹)Î¸^+(rdtdÎ¸â€‹)Î¸^=rdt2d2Î¸â€‹Î¸^âˆ’r(dtdÎ¸â€‹)2r^=Î±Î¸â€‹Î¸^+Î±râ€‹r^â€‹

Angular acceleration

Î±âƒ—=d2Î¸dt2k^=dÏ‰âƒ—dtk^=Î±zk^\vec\alpha = \frac{\mathrm{d}^2\theta}{\mathrm{d}t^2} \hspace{0.05in} \hat{k}=\frac{\mathrm{d}\vec\omega}{\mathrm{d}t}\hspace{0.05in} \hat{k}=\alpha_z \hspace{0.05in} \hat{k} Î±=dt2d2Î¸â€‹k^=dtdÏ‰â€‹k^=Î±zâ€‹k^

entry.title: Center of mass
entry.content:
Definition

The point in a system of mass object which when supported upon solely, can balance the whole system.

Moment

A key concept to understanding center of mass:

Moment=forceÂ Ã—Â distanceM1Â =Â M2â€‰â†’â€‰equilibriumxË‰=centerÂ ofÂ massF1(âˆ’d1+Î”x)+F2(d2+Î”x)=0xË‰=x+Î”x=Î”xxË‰=F1(âˆ’d1)+F2(d2)F1+F2=âˆ‘Mâˆ‘F=âˆ‘midiâˆ‘m\begin{aligned}\textup{Moment}=\textup{force Ã— distance}&\\ \textup{M1 = M2} \, \rightarrow \, \textup{equilibrium}&\\\bar{x}=\textup{center of mass}\\\\ F_1(-d_1+\Delta x)+F_2(d_2+\Delta x)&=0\\ \bar{x}&=x+\Delta x=\Delta x\\ \bar{x}&= \frac{F_1(-d_1)+F_2(d_2)}{F_1+F_2}\\ &=\frac{\sum M}{\sum F}\\ &=\frac{\sum m_id_i}{\sum m}\end{aligned} Moment=forceÂ Ã—Â distanceM1Â =Â M2â†’equilibriumxË‰=centerÂ ofÂ massF1â€‹(âˆ’d1â€‹+Î”x)+F2â€‹(d2â€‹+Î”x)xË‰xË‰â€‹=0=x+Î”x=Î”x=F1â€‹+F2â€‹F1â€‹(âˆ’d1â€‹)+F2â€‹(d2â€‹)â€‹=âˆ‘Fâˆ‘Mâ€‹=âˆ‘mâˆ‘miâ€‹diâ€‹â€‹â€‹

During the calculation, the gravitational acceleration cancels out. Note that the distance used must be perpendicular to the direction of force.

Visual representation Mathematic manifestation
$$\begin{aligned}&\sum_{j=1}^{N}m_j,\vec{r}_{cm,j}=0\end{aligned}$$

The calculus way

Center of mass in 1-dimension

With uniform density

Râƒ—cm=âˆ‘j=1Nmjâ€‰râƒ—s,jmtotal=âˆ«0l(mlâ€‰dxâ€‰Ã—x)m=1mâˆ«0l(ml)xâ€‰dx=12l\begin{aligned} \vec{R}_{cm}& =\frac{\sum_{j=1}^{N}m_j\,\vec{r}_{s,j}}{m_{total}} \\ & = \frac{\int_{0}^{l}(\frac{m}{l}\,\mathrm{d}x\,\times x)}{m} \\ & = \frac{1}{m}\int_{0}^{l}(\frac{m}{l})x\, \mathrm{d}x \\ & = \frac{1}{2}l \end{aligned}Rcmâ€‹â€‹=mtotalâ€‹âˆ‘j=1Nâ€‹mjâ€‹rs,jâ€‹â€‹=mâˆ«0lâ€‹(lmâ€‹dxÃ—x)â€‹=m1â€‹âˆ«0lâ€‹(lmâ€‹)xdx=21â€‹lâ€‹

Center of mass in 2-dimesions

With uniform density

\begin{aligned} \bar{x}=\frac{\sum_{x_1}^{x_2}m_x d_\hat{\imath}}{\sum_{x_1}^{x_2}m_x}&=\frac{\sum_{x_1}^{x_2}\rho A_x x}{\sum_{x_1}^{x_2}\rho A_x} \\&=\frac{\rho \int_{x_1}^{x_2}x(f(x)-g(x))\, \mathrm{d}x}{\rho A} \\&=\frac{1}{A}\int_{x_1}^{x_2}x(f(x)-g(x))\, \mathrm{d}x \end{aligned}

yË‰=âˆ‘x1x2mxdcmÈ·^âˆ‘x1x2mx=âˆ‘x1x2ÏAxf(x)+g(x)2âˆ‘x1x2ÏAx=âˆ«x1x212(f(x)+g(x))â€‰â€‰â€‰Ï(f(x)âˆ’g(x))â€‰dxÏA=12Aâˆ«x1x2f2(x)âˆ’g2(x)â€‰dx\begin{aligned} \bar{y}=\frac{\sum_{x_1}^{x_2}m_{x}d_{cm_{\hat{\jmath}}}}{\sum_{x_1}^{x_2}m_x}&=\frac{\sum_{x_1}^{x_2}\rho A_x \frac{f(x)+g(x)}{2}}{\sum_{x_1}^{x_2}\rho A_x} \\&=\frac{\int_{x_1}^{x_2}\frac{1}{2}(f(x)+g(x))\,\,\,\rho(f(x)-g(x))\,\mathrm{d}x}{\rho A} \\&=\frac{1}{2A}\int_{x_1}^{x_2}f^2(x)-g^2(x)\, \mathrm{d}x \end{aligned}yË‰â€‹=âˆ‘x1â€‹x2â€‹â€‹mxâ€‹âˆ‘x1â€‹x2â€‹â€‹mxâ€‹dcmÈ·^â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹=âˆ‘x1â€‹x2â€‹â€‹ÏAxâ€‹âˆ‘x1â€‹x2â€‹â€‹ÏAxâ€‹2f(x)+g(x)â€‹â€‹=ÏAâˆ«x1â€‹x2â€‹â€‹21â€‹(f(x)+g(x))Ï(f(x)âˆ’g(x))dxâ€‹=2A1â€‹âˆ«x1â€‹x2â€‹â€‹f2(x)âˆ’g2(x)dxâ€‹
